Award.AwardTitle: Taking Games to School: Exploratory Study to Support Game-Based Teaching and Learning In High-School Science Classes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research shows that educational games can enhance students' science learning, but current work leaves teachers dependent on researchers and games companies to provide good games and game-based curricula. This project aims to study how teachers can be involved in making science learning games more effective, and how educational science games can better support good teaching. This project is building a set of software tools, including a tool for annotating screen recordings of activities in games, a teacher data dashboard for information about students' in-game learning, and tools to help teachers customize activities in games to better align with curricular standards. It will conduct studies with successful research-based educational games for learning science, and popularly available educational games from websites such as BrainPop, in a network of teachers who have experience using 'canned' games in their classrooms. The project will find out whether these new tools can enhance teaching and/or learning. It will also help develop a list of the types of customization options teachers need in order to be able to effectively use educational games in their classrooms. If successful, this research could point the way towards new tools that let teachers create activities that turn any game into an educational game, and to better use existing educational games in their classrooms. This could greatly speed up our ability to deliver high-quality learning experiences through educational games.

This project involves a participatory design process in which a small number of experienced teachers will feed into a principled, iterative refinement of prototypes of the tools (annotation, data dashboard, and level-builder) to be prototyped within the Brainplay suite. In the beta testing phase, a hierarchical linear model analysis will be conducted on both student and teacher outcomes in 25 classrooms. In addition to the quantitative analysis, qualitative studies involving classroom observations, focus groups, and teacher journaling will be conducted to examine impact on teaching practices and refine the functional specifications. Project dissemination will take place through the community around the previously-developed Leveling Up games (played around 10,000 times per week), and through existing professional networks such as Edmodo. The project will also work within the games community to help inform possible approaches to logging learning data and allowing teacher customization across all games.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Taking Games to School (TGS) studied how to support STEM teachers in incorporating game-based learning into their classes. TGS aimed to broaden participation in STEM by engaging a wider audience of students in STEM learning, including those who are most at risk for dropping out of school.

The TGS project provided multiple rounds of design research for teacher tools for game-based learning assessment. The investigators worked with teachers involved in EdGE’s parallel research studies (e.g. NSF#1119144, NSF#1502882) to understand their needs and to get feedback on our evolving interface designs. TGS resulted in the design of teacher tools that support “bridging” – the connection between implicit learning in games and STEM classroom content. The resulting TGS prototype designs are based upon research showing that teachers consistently asked for tools that:

-      help them monitor student progress (whole class and individual students) for things like time on task, level reached, gains/improvement, and successes/struggles

-      are actionable so that, for any assessment information, there is also a suggested next step or intervention

-      tell them how game activities links to curriculum (standards in particular)

-      help them identify students who are struggling and what it is they are struggling with (content area, as well as game level) with personalized suggested next steps

-      provide summative tests for a grade that they can provide at the end of class

-      provide suggested and malleable sequences of activities to build toward content standards with related assessments.

The resulting TGS designs served as a starting point for building tools for teachers in the CodePlay Research-Practice Partnership (RPP) between EdGE and Braintree Public Schools, Braintree, MA (NSF#1738574). The TGS project also resulted in new functionality of EdGE’s existing data architecture called DataArcade, to allow real-time information to be passed to teacher tools from formative learning assessments.

Intellectual Merit: TGS leveraged EdGE’s ongoing NSF-supported work to study build a new type of formative assessment that measures implicit learning in digital environments such as games. This line of research uses recent advances in learning analytics to provide information about how learners build knowledge and skill through interest-driven digital activity, such as computer games and coding environments. By identifying what learners can do in games, and providing that information in a real-time and actionable format to teachers, this new form of assessments can empower teachers to differentiate STEM teaching and learning.

Broader Impact: The TGS design process resulted in the research grounded design of tools that are now being developed for teachers the CodePlay RPP in grades 3-8 in Braintree, MA. This RPP will in turn will serve as a national model for how to differentiate teaching and learning in STEM through innovative formative assessments. The focus of this work is to reveal talents of learners who may not do well on traditional tests because of learning differences and/or disengagement. Game-based learning environments enable formative assessment of critical skills that take place where learners play outside of school in their free time. TGS designs are critical in understanding how to provide that assessment information to teachers so that they can effectively differentiate teaching and learning for all their students.
